title: Asteroid Day 2024: A Plethora of New Insights
summary: For Asteroid Day 2024, we’ll be briefly covering updates to various small body missions, and exploring how these vital ambassadors from Earth teach us so much about our origins.

title: Chinese rocket static-fire test results in unintended launch and huge explosion
summary: A rocket stage test firing by Chinese commercial company Space Pioneer ended in catastrophic failure and a dramatic explosion Sunday.

title: Eumetsat moves weather satellite from Ariane 6 to Falcon 9
summary: European weather satellite operator Eumetsat has shifted the upcoming launch of a weather satellite from an Ariane 6 to a Falcon 9, a move that surprised and frustrated European space officials.

summary:
Approximately half a dozen launches supporting NRO's proliferated
architecture are planned for 2024

title: The French Government Funds Commercial In-Orbit Serving Missions
summary: The French government has awarded funding to an Infinite Orbits-led consortium to perform a pair of in-orbit servicing missions. Toulouse-based Infinite Orbits was founded in 2017. The company is working on developing a life-extension vehicle called Endurance and a constellation of small satellites called Orbit Guard, which it will use to offer close-range geostationary asset […]

title: Date for Boeing Starliner CFT Return Still Up in the Air
summary: Today NASA and Boeing pushed back on the narrative that the Starliner crew is stranded in space, but declined to provide a date for when they will return. Starliner is […]

title: SpaceX launches multiple satellites for the NRO from Vandenberg Space Force Base
summary: The mission is described as the second launch supporting the National Reconnaissance Office’s (NRO) “proliferated architecture.” Liftofff from Vandenberg Space Force Base happened at 8:14 p.m. PDT (11:14 p.m. EDT, 0314 UTC).

title: Starliner landing now on indefinite hold for more tests, but NASA insists crew not ‘stranded’ in space
summary: The problem for NASA and Boeing is that the Starliner's service module, which houses the helium lines, thrusters and other critical systems, is discarded before re-entry and burns up in the atmosphere. Engineers will not be able to study the hardware after the fact and as a result, they want to collect as much data as possible before NASA astronauts Butch Wilmore and Sunita Williams head home.
